event_text: Gold production from this area is recorded as approximately 1363 kg from 43,043 tonnes at an average grade of 31.67g/t Au. The gold is associated with boudinaged quartz veins with anastomosing shear zones hosted within pyritic sericite chlorite schists with felspar porphyry dykes occurring within the shear zones. The Yarri mining centre includes several mineralised structures and quartz reefs in east dipping shear structures within the Yarri Monzogranodiorite and along the basalt/monzonite contact. Historic production in the region includes 695kg of gold from 45,559 tonnes at a grade of 15.3g/t Au whilst in more recent times mining in the 1940s and late 1980s at the Porphyry and Million dollar pits totalled 4446 kg of gold from 1.3 million tonnes at a grade of 3.42 g/t Au. Historic gold production at the Edjudina Mining Centre, 6 km SE of the tenement, of 33,215 oz @ 46.9 g/t of gold was recorded, sourced from contiguous underground mines developed on series of sub-parallel quartz lodes over a strike length of 1.4 kilometres between 1898 and 1939.

event_text: Massive sulphide bodies are usually fairly narrow and of short strike length, and they are often highly conductive. If sufficient pyrrhotite or magnetite is present, a magnetic anomaly may be associated with the EM anomaly. Stratiform deposits, however, commonly contain disseminated sulphide mineralisation, and electromagnetic responses over such bodies may be diffuse to almost non-existent. Strike length can be considerable in the case of stratiform deposits, and magnetic signatures, if any, tend to parallel the trend of the regional geology. SPECTREM EM anomalies are graded A, B, C or D, with grade A anomalies being the most favorable.
label: False

event_text: The Siliciclastic Sequences are the youngest Archaean rocks and are predominantly turbidites but include carbonaceous shale, sandstone, conglomerate, chert and magnetic shale (BIF). A regional, four-stage, contractional deformation history has been constructed for the Eastern Goldfields (Morey, 2007): D1 - the earliest shortening event is characterised by a roughly NS directed thrusting and recumbent folding that resulted in large scale repetition of the greenstone sequences. D2 - a major stage of ENE-WSW shortening which gave rise to NNW trending, regional, upright folds and major reverse faulting/thrusting. This deformation episode was associated with multiple shortening episodes and intervening extensional stages. D3 - further ENE-WSW shortening reactivated NNW-trending D2 structures to produce dominantly sinistral strikeslip ductile faults.
label: False

event_text: Uplift accompanied by extensive erosion and weathering took place from Late Cretaceous through the Tertiary in the Perth Basin. Numerous marine incursions occurred during the Late Tertiary to Pleistocene period that eroded a marine platform extending inland for a distance of around 30km to the Darling and Whicher Scarps. Unconformably overlying the Cretaceous Leederville Formation in the Southern Perth Basin is a paralic sequence of marine-estuarine, beach and dune deposits, locally enriched in heavy mineral sands and known as the Yoganup Formation. This is variably overlain to the west by the Guilford Formation and by later alluvial fan deposits and thin aeolian quartz and calcarenite dunes of the Bassendean, Spearwood and Quindalup dune systems. There have been numerous phases of HM accumulation, ascribed broadly to the Capel (0-10m RL) and the Yoganup (20-80m RL) palaeo-shorelines.

event_text: Mapping by GSWA has led to definition of the Glengarry Basin (Gee, 1979 & 1987, and Gee & Grey, 1993) which has more recently been subdivided into the Yerrida, Bryah and Padbury Basins (Pirajno et al., 1998 & 2000). Due to the complex structural framework, combined with cover obscuring many areas, it is considered that further revision of the stratigraphy of the area will take place as more information becomes available. The region has a history of copper production at Thaduna from epigenetic, fault-related mineralisation, and gold production further to the west at the Peak Hill mining centre where epigenetic gold in quartz reefs were exploited. The Horseshoe Lights copper-gold mine, located in the north-western part of the Bryah Basin has produced some 300,000 oz gold and 50,000t copper. The mineralisation is hosted within felsic schist of the Narracoota Volcanics and comprises massive, disseminated and stringer sulphides with a Cu-Au-Ag-Pb-Zn association, with GSWA interpreting the deposit as volcanogenic massive sulphide (VMS) style.

event_text: This fault is a major structure, estimated to extend in a northerly direction for some 150 km. The Inglewood, Tarnagulla, Eganstown and Ballarat goldfields are situated from 3 5 km west of the Campbelltown fault. Gold mineralisation in the Campbelltown Goldfield is associated with the faulting of tightly folded north trending anticlines and synclines. Old mine workings extend over a distance of 5 km, and occur in two lines (~ reef systems), about 500 metres apart. The apparent en echelon disposition of the reefs along the two reef lines implies the presence of a shear zone, informally termed here as the Campbelltown Shear Zone.
label: False

event_text: While further exploration for nickel has been conducted since the early 1970s and a best result of 3m @ 3.05% Ni was intersected in a 1998 Bundarra Holdings Pty Ltd RC hole, an economic nickel accumulation is yet to be discovered. The nearest economic nickel deposit is located approximately 24km to the northeast of the Spargos prospect at the Nepean nickel mine, which is at the southern end of the Coolgardie greenstone belt and was discovered by Metals Exploration NL in 1968. Twelve RC holes for a total of 2,933 metres were completed at the Benari Prospect on E15/913 (Figure 7). The drill programme was designed to test MLEM QVR_C98/2004_2013S Page 15 anomalies which were coincident with historical VTEM anomalies and geochemical (nickel and copper) anomalies. The drilling intersected the defined MLTEM conductors but most were found to be sulphidic sediments, however, ultramafic lithologies were confirmed in some holes.

event_text: The results follow the similar trend discovered by Kurnalpi Golds RAB program although it does not seem to be continuous along strike as little mineralisation was intersected at the north of Zandor and between the central trend and the southern workings. Of particular interest is KURB164, where a high grade but narrow quartz vein, hosted in massive basalt was intersected at 63m. To the south of Zandor, very little anomalous gold was intersected and although the historic workings were not targeted directly, the results were disappointing. There is no strong continuity from the central Zandor trend to the south and although some quartz stockwork systems within silicified basalts were intercepted they carried little grade, with exception of KURB230, KURB242 and KURB247. The mineralisation intercepted in these three holes is hosted by quartz-carbonate altered dolerite proximal to quartz stockwork systems.

Native vegetation should not be cleared if the clearing of the vegetation is likely to cause or exacerbate the incidence or intensity of flooding Rainfall totals of more than 100mm are common within the Pilbara region due to tropical lows that move over land, and when tropical lows occur within a few weeks of each other the chance of flooding is enhanced (MWH 2009). Intense flooding and large cyclones have the potential to reshape the landscape, in particular streamlines, pools, rivers and sandy channel beds making the Pilbara region varied and inconsistent in terms of surface water and drainage. event_text: A total of 6 samples were taken for NITON portable XRF analysis within tenement E77/1372 (Figure 5), which has since been surrendered. This work is being synthesised with the historical work to assist the target generation and exploration planning of the remaining project tenure. The current state of knowledge suggests that the Lady Agnes prospect is comprised of a folded sequence of gabbro, pyroxenite and serpentinite approximately 7km long, closing to the northwest (Figure 3). It is unclear whether the stratigraphy represents a large differentiated ultramafic intrusion or a sequence of extrusive komatiites, however, the layered, cumulate nature of the Lady Agnes ultramafic sequence is indicative of nickel sulphide host rocks. event_text: The preservation of chert mesolayers within zones of hematite alteration suggests that these jaspilite occurrences essentially represent domains that were exposed to the same, second-stage hypogene fluid that precipitated hematite in the orebodies at Windarling. However, in contrast, these more peripheral hematitic alteration domains lacked the earlier hypogene dolomite alteration and were therefore not subject to the same level of iron-oxide concentration that accompanied the leaching of dolomite. The other line of field evidence that points to the formation of jaspilite during the second-stage hypogene hydrothermal event (that formed iron-ore mineralisation) is the presence of massive to irregular bodies of red and translucent chalcedony within some jaspilite units. These jasperoid bodies display transitional or diffuse boundaries with the host jaspilite units, and may be up to 50 m long and extend across strike for up to 20 m. Chalcedony takes the form of diffuse replacement zones and more distinct dilational veins. The veins appear to have formed during a progressive hydrothermal event, during which early hematitic chalcedonic replacement zones or veins are cross-cut or replaced by later barren white chalcedony.
label: False

event_text: Mylonitic rocks are comparatively abundant in a deformation zone up to 10km wide, with north-northeast and northnorthwest trending structures apparently having been rotated into the Darling trend. This shear zone was referred to as the proto-Darling Fault and Donnybrook-Nannup Shear zone. b. ALTERATION The Donnybrook project is interpreted to host epithermal style mineralisation. Epithermal deposits are distinguished from Achaean metamorphic quartz vein-lode deposits by gangue mineral types and textures, alteration styles and metallic assemblages. Distinctive criteria which distinguish the epithermal deposits in the Donnybrook region are: Platy textures with silica replacing original carbonate and/or sulphate minerals Breccias, re-cemented by silica, especially quartz and chalcedony-jasper-chert (locally laminated) Multiple fine quartz veining/stockworking Grey pyritic silica and pyritic chert breccias Wall rock alteration is best illustrated from the diamond core from holes within the Donnybrook Project.

event_text: EIS Final Report Ashburton Monster Project Avocet Resources 13 EIS Final Report Ashburton Monster Project Avocet Resources 14 Interpretation The results of the RC drilling show that the iron-rich and banded cherts observed and mapped at surface are primarily a weathering effect and do not appear to extend to depth. This makes the model of a Homestake-style deposit less likely, although there are still a number of iron-rich surface outcrops that remain untested. The intersections of significant thicknesses of graphitic shale in a number of drill holes, especially MORC001 and MORC005, provide an explanation for the Airborne EM anomaly. The Au/Ag prospectivity along the strike length of the Monster vein structure is limited to the far western end of the drilled area and the highest gold grades were associated with a mapped cross cutting fault structure with a deep weathering profile. Slightly lower but still anomalous Ag and Au in the west are also associated with pyrite-rich quartz veining in the main target quartz vein (Figure 13).

event_text: (Seymour, D.B et al, 1988; Powell, C. & Horwitz, R.C 1994) Powell and Horwitz (1994) proposes the subdivision of the Wyloo Group into upper and lower sub-groups based on the presence of a distinct unconformable geological boundary separating the two groups resulting from tectonic activity in the formation of the Ashburton Trough (i.e. Mount McGrath Formation unconformable overlies the Duck Creek Dolomite.) This hypothesis is supported by the locality of deposition of the sediments that comprise both the lower and upper Wyloo Groups. Sediments belonging to both the lower and upper Wyloo Groups are present only within the Mount McGrath and Ashburton Trough respectively. This geological unconformity that separates the Wyloo Group into separate upper and lower subgroups was created during the down faulting and subsidence at the latter parts of the lower Wyloo Group sedimentation in the Mount McGrath Trough, resulting from lateral tectonic extensions and the formation of the Ashburton trough.

event_text: Page 9 of 24 In the Boorara domain, more complex lithostratigraphic successions are recorded because early felsic volcanism in distinct centres developed at the same time as the regional extensive komatiite volcanic flows. These units generally trend north-east, and prominent structural lineations in the form of shear zones trend northwesterly. The main structural element of the Boorara domain is the south plunging Scotia Kanowna Anticline, which contains the prospective Highway Ultramafic overlying tholeiitic basalts. This structure is sometimes referred to as the Scotia- Kanowna Dome. The Gordons tenements lie on the eastern limb of the Scotia Kanowna Dome.

event_text: The Tertiary palaeochannels of the Lake Raeside project areas may have the potential to host roll-front uranium deposits such as those in the Gawler Craton of South Australia. The presence of organic matter or pyrite in and adjacent to the palaeochannels can present an ideal redox trap for the precipitation of uranium. The combination of uraniferous source rocks and potential trap sites could make the Lake Raeside palaeochannels prospective exploration targets for roll-front uranium. Carbonate is often formed when organic matter is oxidised and any uranium associated with it can be deposited as calcrete. Radiometric anomalies along sections of the Lake Raeside drainage system offer excellent readily testable drill targets for future uranium exploration.

event_text: The oldest unit recorded from E04/2151 is the Late Devonian (Famennian), Windjana Limestone which, along with the overlying Nullara Limestone, forms the major cliffs of the Oscar Range. Extensive outcrops of the Early Carboniferous, Gumhole Formation and Fairfield Formation are mapped to the north of the limestone cliffs. Within the tenement, limestones, dolomites and a variety of clastic sedimentary lithologies have been encountered in shallow drilling and pitting. Brown to black carbonaceous siltstone and brown to white, fine to medium grained sandstones dominate the clastic sedimentary sequence.

event_text: It lies at the convergence of Australias main Proterozoic structural trends that reflect the amalgamation of the North, West, and South Australian Cratons (Smithies, 2013). Within the West Musgrave province the nature and age of the basement is poorly constrained with intrusive components as old as c.1600 Ma and banded gneiss dominated by material derived from volcanic, volcanoclastics and sedimentary protoliths (Smithies, 2008). The 1335-1295 Ma Mount West Orogeny and 1220-1155 Ma Musgravian Orogeny are major crustal events that involved intrusion of early I-type Warakurna Supersuite and later A-type Pitjantjara Supersuite granites, high-grade crustal reworking, intensive deformation, and widespread ultra-high temperature metamorphism (Smithies, 2008). The Ngaanyatjarra Rift is the main structural expression of the Mesoproterozoic Giles Event which saw the earlier Mesoproterozoic rocks of the Musgrave Province extensively intruded and covered by bimodal magmatic rocks of the Warakurna Supersuite. Volcanic rocks of the Warakurna Supersuite (Bentley Supergroup) are the dominant component of the Bentley Basin the fill of the Ngaanyatjarra Rift.

event_text: On 21 November 2013 IGO withdrew from the agreement. 4.0 GEOLOGY AND MINERALISATION 4.1 Regional Geology The Eastern Goldfield Province occupies the eastern third of the Yilgarn Craton. It is a typical Archaean granite-greenstone terrain characterised by large areas of granitoid and broad to narrow, linear and arcuate belts of greenstone. The greenstones are deformed and metamorphosed to greenschist facies or higher and comprise thick mafic to ultramafic volcanic sequences and intrusives, felsic and intermediate volcanic sequences pelitic and psammitic sedimentary sequences and inter-bedded chert, banded iron formation and shale. Granitoid intrusions and regional deformation involving multiple episodes of folding and strike faulting have disrupted the greenstone sequences.

event_text: The drill contractor Yearlong Contracting Pty Ltd utilised a tractor-mounted vacuum drilling mechanism to drill 48 mm diameter holes. Holes were drilled on an initial 160 metre by 160 metre spacing. Where drilling intersected significant thicknesses of laterite drilling was infilled to 80 metre spacing. Samples were collected at 0.5 metre intervals in the vacuum flask and the entire sample was submitted to Nagrom in Kelmscott, WA for analysis. Samples are initially assayed using Fourier Transform InfraRed Spectroscopy (FTIR) and those samples showing inferred Available Al2O3 (Av.Al2O3) greater than 25% are further assayed using BOM digest to test for Av.Al2O3 and Reactive SiO2 (Re.SiO2).

event_text: At 152 m depth high grade nickel copper sulphide veins were intersected within the basal contact zone of the Mulga Tank dunite, the veins dip steeply to the south and are sub- parallel to the drill-hole, which was not orientated optimally to intersect them. A 50 m thick zone of widespread and locally abundant late fractures and veinlets of chalcopyrite, pyrite and lesser sphalerite has been intersected from about 165 m (Photos 5a and 5b). The top 20 m of this copper-zinc zone comprises a 20 metre wide zone of extensive pyrrhotite that occurs in narrow veins and breccia zones and also as disseminations throughout the sedimentary rocks and basalt (Photo 5c). This is the source of the Upper target at Conductor 2. The zone of copper veining extends for a further 30 m down hole and at 180 m depth is coincident with a second 10 m thick zone of disseminated pyrrhotite within a unit of black shale, which is probably the source of the lower conductor at Conductor 2.

event_text: The greenstone belt corresponds to the western most subdivision of the extensive north-northwest trending Norseman-Wiluna Greenstone Belt and covers a total strike extent of approximately 150km. The Ularring Greenstone Belt occupies an extensive sequence of mafic and ultramafic rocks with interbedded volcanogenic sediments and felsic to intermediate volcanics. The geology is structurally complex, consisting of cross cutting and regional shear zones, a regional antiformsynform-antiform sequence (in the southern hinge region at Mt Ida), reverse faulting, extensive deformation, intrusive porphyries and basal ultramafic contacts (see figure 2). The Ida structural corridor, incorporating the Ida Shear Zone, represents an extensive regional lineament that has been recognised over a distance of 500km. The regional structural feature juxtaposes the Kalgoorlie Terrane from the Southern Cross Terrane and incorporates the Ularring Greenstone Belt (figure 3.1.1 1).

event_text: Some of the larger D2 folds are thought to have been re-orientated during D3, from an original N-S trend, into trends more closely aligned with the D3 shear zones (e.g. Bungalbin synform and Broadbents antiform; Fig. Metamorphic grade in the supracrustal rocks of the central Southern Cross Domain ranges from very low to low grade in the interior of the larger greenstone belts, through to medium to high grade along the margins of the larger belts, and across the full width of some of the narrower greenstone belts 4 (Ahmat 1986; Chen and Wyche 2001). event_text: Gold mineralisation is hosted by northwest, north-northwest and east-west trending shear zones and is typically associated with quartz, iron carbonate, iron chlorite and sericite alteration and variable (minor to 5%) pyrite and arsenopyrite mineralisation. The mineralised portions of shear zones tend to occur on the contact or close to a contact between two lithologies. Gold mineralisation can also be associated with quartz-sericite-pyrite-silica altered dacitic to andesitic fragmentals that are coincident with shallow north-plunging quartz boudins or chert boudins within shallow north or moderately east-dipping extensional (lag) shears. The chert boudins represent pipes of silicified pyritic dacite or andesite. 4.2 Mineralisation The dominant structural features within the Rabbit Warren South Project are a NNWtrending foliation with mineral lineations plunging at 40 to the north.

event_text: Four samples were taken by Halls Creek Minerals in 1994-95, with mineralised rock fragments returning 46.2%Cu, and three soil samples returning between 0.38% and 0.53%Cu. A two metre wildcat auger sample was also taken and assayed 0.38% over the first metre. Follow up work was planned, but the JV switched to Brown Dog NL the following year. Analysis showed most samples to be between 10ppm and 390ppm Cu, with a maximum of 0.215%Cu, and a coherent anomaly over 2km strike length and up to 500m wide was defined (>50ppm Cu). event_text: The banded iron-formation layers represent periods of diminished or no supply of clastic material into a relatively deep basin. The Mount Belches Formation is intruded by late granitoid intrusions. In the southern and southeastern parts of the Bulong Anticline, the Hickman Find and Duchess of York prospects are located at the faulted contact of the felsic volcanic sequence with the overlying, but younger mafic volcanic and intrusive rock sequence. At the Transfind mining centre the major part of the historical production is from the Transfind workings with gold mineralisation in and along quartz veins within felsic epiclastic metasediments. event_text: Strong weathering within the project area has resulted in a gold enriched pisolitic surface layer, totally gold depleted saprolite and dispersed gold anomalism at the base of weathering. Initial RAB drilling of prospects in many cases appears too shallow to intersect anomalous or fresh bedrock mineralisation. Primary gold mineralisation is associated with quartz-pyritepyrrhotite stringer veins within anastomosing shears zones in pelitic sediments at Anomaly 1 and altered amphibolitic units within prospects on the Crossroads Trend. The Crossroads Trend extends for over 12 kilometres and follows a sheared granite margin also referred to as the Cockatoo Shear Zone. Along the Crossroads Trend deeper drilling intersected broad, anastomosing shear zones containing low-grade gold mineralisation associated with quartz stringers and pyrite pyrrhotite veins and disseminations.

event_text: The Red Eye project area represents an opportunity for new mineralisation models to be applied to the typically orogenic/shear zone focused exploration targeting within the Kalgoorlie Terrane. Field reconnaissance has led to the identification of USTs and miarolitic cavities at the carapace zone of the Scotia Dome (Figure 3). These are typical indicators of a magmatic-hydrothermal transitional environment which is conducive for hydrostatic failure, brecciation and associated mineralisation (Doran, 2013). A number of deposit types are characteristically hosted within these settings including Porphyry Cu-Mo-Au, Intrusion Related Gold Deposits (IRGD), Granitoid-Hosted Au and Skarn W-Mo-Au The Timbarra gold deposit in New South Wales can be used as an analogue for IRGD-type mineralisation. Timbarra is a Triassic aged, disseminated gold system containing ~400 Koz total resources within several ore bodies hosted within the carapace zone of a monzogranite (Mustard, 2001).

event_text: The tenements were acquired primarily as high potential targets for concealed channel iron deposits (CID) as they are located upstream of the Marillana paleochannel that hosts the Yandicogina CID operations of both BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. Secondary exploration targets were bedded iron (BID) and detrital iron (DID) deposits hosted or derived from the Brockman Iron Formation. Geological mapping at 1:25,000 scale was carried out over all of the tenements but only identified small outcrops of martite goethite mineralisation in the Joffre Member of the Brockman Iron Formation with even smaller areas of associated detrital mineralisation and canga. These outcropping areas were unable to be drill tested because of the inability to obtain approval from the Banjima traditional owners (as well as the steep terrain). event_text: The Laverton Domain sequence may represent autochthonous basement to the younger rock units in the Edjudina and Linden Domains. The Duketon Domain of the Burtville Terrane includes c. 2810Ma intermediate and felsic volcanic rocks and associated maficultramafic rocks in the central and eastern parts of the Duketon Greenstone Belt as well as greenstone assemblages dominated by mafic and ultramafic volcanic and fine-grained sedimentary rocks. A modification of this tectonic subdivision was proposed by Pawley et al (2012) based on remapping, new geophysical, isotopic and geochemical data. These authors subdivided the former Burtville Terrane into the redefined older Burtville Terrane, which includes the former Duketon and Merolia domains, and the newly recognized younger Yarmana Terrane. The Hootanui Fault separates the Kurnalpi and Burtville Terranes, while the Burtville and Yarmarna Terranes are separated by the Yarmana Shear Zone.

event_text: The key is to understand the possible proxies in available datasets that represent these processes. By using a systems approach the explorer is no longer dependent upon the influence of only one particular component of orebody formation, such as structure. In this study Optiro focused on the mineral system model outlined by the Predictive Mineral Discovery * Cooperative Research Centre, which seeks to answer five questions as to why an orebody is where it is. These questions relate to the geodynamics, architecture and structure, fluid reservoirs (source), the fluid flow drivers and pathways and depositional mechanisms (Figure 5.1). This method of exploration has been successfully applied in the Yilgarn and other gold orogenic belts and has led to the prediction and discovery of multiple million-ounce deposits.

event_text: Warrawoona Stage (3525 3420 Ma) is the oldest event and involved the eruption of the Warrawoona Group volcanic rocks and emplacement of granitic rocks of the Callina and Tambina Supersuites. Two periods of deformation and contact-style metamorphism also occurred during this stage. The second formational event, Kelly Stage (3350 3290 Ma), involved the deposition of Kelly Group volcanic rocks, emplacement of the Emu Pool Supersuite and an interval of substantial deformation and metamorphism. The final Sulpur Springs Stage (3275 -3225 Ma) encompassed deposition of the Sulphur Springs Group, emplacement of the Cleland Supersuite and another major period of deformation and metamorphism. The GSWA interpreted bedrock geology of the project area is shown on Figure 2.

event_text: There is a gross relationship between the location of Archaean lode-gold deposits and crustal-scale deformation zones in the Yilgarn Craton. A similar relationship has been noted in Canada (Robert 1990). Despite this large-scale relationship, gold mineralisation is rarely hosted in first-order structures, and deposits are instead hosted in second and lower order structures, which may or may not show a direct geometric relationship to the large-scale deformation zones (e.g. Eisenlohr et al. The general lack of mineralisation within the major structures suggest that, if the structures are interlinked and the major structures acted as fluid conduits, they did so at deeper crustal levels than those currently exposed in most gold deposits.

The succession is confined to the east along the western margin of the extensive northeast Pilbara Sub Basin of the Fortescue Basin. The Fortescue Group uncomformably overlies, or is faulted against, the Mount Edgar Granitic Complex, the Marble Bar, Kelly and McPhee Greenstone belts, and the Gorge Creek Group. event_text: Lithologies are predominantly metamorphosed to amphibolite facies; however there are remnants of unaltered basalts and sediments in the more central portions of the belt. The mafic volcanics are thought to belong to the Warrawoona Group; the clastic sediments are tentatively assigned to the Corboy Formation and the BIFs and cherts to the Cleaverville Formation. The prospective Cleaverville Formation usually occurs near the centre, sitting on older Warrawoona Group volcano-sediments, which occupy the flanks near the granites. Cleaverville Formation sediments occupy a complex central position between the outer amphibolites and the three inner bodies of maficultramafics and sit unconformably on the Warrawoona Group over most of the area, but are interpreted to overlie Corboy Formation sediments in the south. They are dominated by fine-grained sediments, which include siltstones, interbedded siltstones and cherts, BIFs and bedded cherts.

A more precise subdivision of the greenstone packages could be achieved by analysis at more detailed scales (eg 1:10,000) incorporating additional outcrop and drill hole data, if available. There is limited evidence of discrete intrusive contacts and much of the area interpreted as granitoid may represent older basement in which the greenstone sequences have evolved.

event_text: The distribution, composition, thickness and areal extent of these deposits are the result of interacting depositional and erosional controls related to climate, parent rocks, drainage, topography and vegetation (Hickman, Smurthwaite, Brown and Davy, 1992). 3.2 Historical Exploration The existence of bauxite in the Darling Range was established early last century but exploration by a commercial entity did not commence until the late 1950s. Significant bauxite laterite deposits were discovered in the Darkling Range by Western Mining Corporation in 1957. The deposits were deemed economically viable and WMC established a joint venture called Western Aluminium No Liability (WANL) and a special mining lease covering an area of 12,619km2 of mainly forested Crown land was granted in 1961. Scout drilling and sampling of the duricrust revealed significant deposits in the Jarrahdale-Dwellingup region to the south-east of Perth, which were later exploited after Aluminium Company of America (Alcoa) joined the WANL venture to become Alcoa World Alumina Australia in 1977.

event_text: Key points to note regarding the DHTEM results are: The response recorded in LLRC0002 is consistent with a conductor lying below the end of the drill hole (Figure 6 and Figure 7). This is also consistent with the location of the minimum coupling position in the surface MLTEM profiles. This provides a useful constraint on the possible location of the conductor it cannot lie to the north of the end of LLRC0002, otherwise the polarity of the response would be opposite to what we have observed. A highly complex DHTEM response (Figure 8) consistent with multiple zones of intersected and off-hole conductive material was recorded in LLDD0001 drilled underneath LLRC0002. It has not been possible to devise a model that fits these data, but the key conclusion remains: the hole has intersected the stratigraphy responsible for the observed response.

event_text: The apparent limited strike length of the anomaly itself is not sufficient to constitute a discrete target: an electrically thick conductor composed of several sub-parallel layers will give rise to a power-law response, even if it is strike-limited. The limited strike length of the observed MLTEM response has puzzled some geoscientists involved in the project, given the fairly unremarkable lithologies intersected by LLRC0002 and LLDD0001. There is apparently no reason why black shale that forms an extensive planar surface should become conductive over a strike length of 200m or so, but remain non-conductive elsewhere. Nevertheless, this is a common phenomenon that has frustrated explorers for as long as electromagnetic techniques have been used to target drill holes. An internal geophysical review of the existing data acquired at the Nessie prospect was conducted by IGO geophysicist David Johnson.

event_text: There are two main models for the genesis of these deposits. One model suggests Supergene alteration of the BIF to develop goethitemartite ores. The resulting mineralisation then undergoes burial metamorphism to form microplaty haematite. The other model puts forward hypogene alteration of martite enriched BIF by replacement of the gangue with goethite and/or deposition of microplaty haematite. This is followed by Supergene alteration that deposits goethite and involves some leaching of the rock.

event_text: Of these members, the Mount Newman Member is host to the major deposits presently being mined and consists of a thick succession of BIF, shale, and carbonate rocks. The Brockman Iron Formation consists of BIF, shale and chert and is divided into the Dales Gorge, Mt Whaleback, Joffre, and Yandicoogina Shale Members. The Dales Gorge Member is host to the majority of iron ore mineralisation, with Tom Price, Paraburdoo, Whaleback, and Rhodes Ridge being typical examples. During the Tertiary, a series of erosion-deposition-hardpanisation (ferricrete) cycles resulted in the regionally extensive Hamersley surfaces that can contain economic Detrital Iron Mineralisation. These surfaces have subsequently been eroded by the existing drainage system, often preserving remnants of the Hamersley surfaces in mesas.

event_text: The last available public domain mineral exploration report detailing previous exploration activities in the area was by Viceroy Australia in 2001 around the time it went into voluntary administration. The previous exploration tenements covering WANLs Bent Bear project tenement areas were relinquished in November 2005 and WANL made its Mt Holland-Bear tenement applications shortly thereafter in December 2005. The previous work has identified low grade Cu-Mo-Au sulphide mineralisation hosted by the Bent Bear Schist that dips shallowly towards the east and extends outside of the tenement block at shallow depths. An overlying tremolitic ultramafic unit, exposed along the eastern margin of the tenement block, also dips towards the east and outside of the tenement block at shallow depths. This ultramafic has been previously tested for nickel without success.

event_text: There are also small outcrops of BIF/chert, quartzite, felsic schist and mafic schist that dip at 30-40o towards the NE. This area covers the Bent Bear Schist Cu-MoAu prospect. The low grade Cu-Mo-Au sulphide mineralisation hosted by the Bent Bear Schist outcrops along the eastern margin of WANLs Bent Bear tenement block and dips shallowly towards the east outside of the tenement block area, ie, only the shallowest portions of the mineralisation are contained within WANLs tenement block. The Bent Bear Schist is a distinctive metasedimentary or metavolcanic unit sandwiched between underlying (basal) tholeiitic mafic schists and overlying tremolite-rich rocks (ultramafics). Its western contact with the underlying mafic schists is not well defined and is thought to be transitional.

event_text: 5 E09/781 Annual Technical Report, Year Ending 16th June, 2007 6 E09/781 Annual Technical Report, Year Ending 16th June, 2007 Recent mapping shows that the metasediments around the main ultramafic comprise pelites and sandstones. The pelites include quartz-muscovite schists and knotted schists and a banded iron marker bed. It is possible that intrusion of the ultramafic magma through this sediment pile could have contaminated it with sulphur and felsic material, facilitating sulphide segregation. The knotted schists indicate the host metasediments have undergone amphibolite facies metamorphism, where as the ultramafic appears to be lower grade (i.e. greenschist facies mineral assemblage) and is less deformed.

event_text: Most of these ultramafics were subjected to reconnaissance exploration for nickel during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Nickel gossans were noted at Byro East (also called Meegea) and copper gossans documented at Byro West, but no significant nickel or copper deposits have been discovered. Subeconomic chromite seams are known at Imagi (sometimes spelt Iniagi) and Taccabba. Anomalous platinum and palladium geochemistry was reported in the 1970s at Byro, Meegea and Erong, but the old analyses are unreliable. More recently Platinum Australia has discovered PGE anomalies at Imagi, south west of the Byro project.

event_text: The Byro Project area is approximately 28 kilometres east of the station along a pastoral track past Deep Well and Melun Bore. Station tracks and existing exploration tracks provide reasonable access within the licence except after heavy rain as unsealed roads and tracks become impassable. As the main ultramafic body is only sparsely vegetated four-wheel drive access to most of the body is possible except where prevented by large boulder rubble. The smaller eastern ultramafic bodies are in more heavily vegetated terrain dissected by numerous creeks making vehicular access difficult. The area is within the Byro and Milly Milly Pastoral Leases.

event_text: The cause of metamorphism has been linked to the intrusive plutonism and is evident from the occurrence of low pressure metamorphic mineral assemblages. The peak metamorphic conditions prevailed during the main D2 compressional event; granites intruded during D2 are deformed by the D3 shear zones. It is possible that the timing of peak metamorphism varied across the region because of differences in emplacement ages of various granitoid bodies. Both gold and iron deposits are considered as potential exploration targets in the area. The timing of gold mineralization remains unresolved.

event_text: The Pilbara region of Western Australia has been largely overlooked for base metals by modern explorers due to its remoteness away from better known gold and nickel sulphide deposits of the Archaean Yilgarn of WA. Areas such as the Eastern Goldfields region received the bulk of Western Australias exploration expenditure for many years. More recently, the Pilbara region has seen increasing interest for gold and base metal exploration due to higher commodity prices, the recognition of its mineral potential, developing infrastructure and historical inactivity. Segue took control of the Pardoo Project from Westralian in October/ November 2006. Work completed during the 2007 exploration year includes; 1 Geophysical modelling of Westralian electromagnetic data 2 Helicopter-based VTEM geophysical survey.

event_text: The principal exploration target is nickel/ copper sulphide mineralization associated with the regional east-northeasterly trending De Grey Structural Zone, also known as the Pardoo Fault. The project area contains 25km of effective strike of this zone. Previous exploration has identified existing low-grade, JORC-code compliant resources of nickel and copper at the Highway prospect. Additionally, the project is prospective for iron ore in the form of primary BIF, secondary enrichment and/or channel iron deposits. Importantly the project area contains the same geological sequence that hosted the historic Goldsworthy iron ore mine and produced 157Mt of high grade hematite over 16 years until 1982.

event_text: Again, in June 2005 an airborne geophysical survey was flown to collect magnetic, radiometric and elevation data over a large portion of the project area. Historical diamond drill core from the Highway and Supply Well Prospects was reexamined in an attempt to relate higher grade nickel sulphide mineralization to host rock and adjacent lithological units. Assay intervals by previous explorers were broad and appeared to crosscut geological boundaries effectively diluting nickel and copper concentrations in the sampled intervals. Re-sampling revealed for the first time the presence of high grade nickel sulphide in the mineralised system grading 5.85% nickel over a 0.5m interval at the Supply Well Prospect and 2.11% nickel over a 1m interval at the Highway Prospect. This has been important in establishing that high-tenor nickel sulphide intervals do exist (albeit narrow zones) within the lower-grade ore zones in the project area.

event_text: A review of all geophysical data available on the project highlighted a strong gravity anomaly in the order of 8 x 5 km situated in the northern part of the Highway tenement. The significance of this feature has not previously been appreciated. It is believed to represent a large and classic target for nickel, copper and platinum group element (PGE) mineralisation in the form of a mafic to ultramafic intrusion with defining annular magnetic anomalies. The Pardoo Nickel Project lies on the Port Hedland (SF 50-4) 1:250,000 and the Pardoo 1:100,000 scale geological mapping sheets. Exposure throughout this area is primarily limited to a few regions where strike ranges rise abruptly out of the typically flat Quaternary aged floodplain and minor areas of low-lying granite hills The Pilbara Craton consists of two different tectonic components: older underlying Archaean granite-greenstone basement that was formed between 3600 and 2800 million years ago, and a younger, unconformably overlying Archaean- Proterozoic aged volcanosedimentary sequence called the Mt Bruce Supergroup occupying the Hamersley Basin that is believed to have been deposited between 2770 and 2400 million years ago.

event_text: The Pardoo Nickel Project is located on the northern edge of the largest of these units called the East Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane. This northern portion of the Pilbara block incorporates the southern preserved margin of thin, on lapping Mesozoic aged Lambert Shelf and younger sediments of the Northern Carnarvon Basin. Historical geophysical work has confirmed these on lapping sediments and windblown sands cover the basement Palaeoarchaean to Mesoarchaean aged (c.3500-2930Ma), East Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane in the tenure that hosts the Pardoo mineralisation. The De Grey Structural Zone is a large, regionally pervasive structure, trending east-northeasterly that becomes the Tabba Tabba Shear Zone further to the southwest. It is believed Page 16 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 that the De Grey Structural Zone is integral to the mineralisation at Highway and Supply Well prospects.

CRA Exploration Pty Ltd (now Rio Tinto Ltd) identified low-grade resources of nickel and copper mineralisation at the Highway Prospect in the northern Pilbara between 1989 and 1995 following extensive regional scale exploration. Nickel resources were located in conjunction with similar mineralisation at the adjacent Supply Well Prospect. Westralian Nickel Ltd (Westralian) was granted tenure over these projects in 2004 with the intention of developing resources through targeted exploration for the benefit of shareholders.
label: True

event_text: Under the terms of the agreement Mithril has the right to earn a 65% interest in Segues 100% owned Pardoo Nickel Project through expenditure of $5,500,000 over 4 years. Mithril conducted ground-based geophysics (figure 1), diamond drilling (4 holes-999.5 m), reassaying of historic sample pulps, specific gravity determinations and bio-oxidation heap leaching amenability trials in the 2007-2008 reporting year (table 1). Previous historical drilling at both the Highway and Supply Well prospects has identified an unusual style of disseminated and semi-massive nickel-copper sulphide mineralization that appears stratabound and discordant within meta-sediments, cherts and possible ultramafic rocks. Historical drilling at Highway has outlined an 800m long by 50-75m wide, disseminated and semi-massive nickel copper sulphide system containing 5-30% sulphide minerals. The mineralized zone is stratabound and largely discordant to the lithology which dips 70-85o to the north, suggesting it is influenced by faulting or shearing.
label: False

event_text: Observations of existing diamond core samples confirm the presence of remobilized sulphides associated with major faulting and deformation. Sulphide minerals form clots to wispy bands of remobilised mineralization, usually subparallel with cleavage. Where chert bands occur within the host schist, the mineralisation is dominantly vein-type, usually at irregular orientations. A historical inferred resource has been estimated from drilling at Highway, which is open along strike and at depth, of 37Mt of 0.3%Ni and 0.12% Cu using a 0.1% Ni cut-off. A higher grade core of 5 million tonnes grading better than 0.5% nickel, 0.13% copper has also been delineated to 200m vertical depth on 100m and 200m spaced sections.

event_text: The Pardoo Nickel Project provides an excellent fit with the Companys exploration and development strategy. Geographically, it is well positioned being 15 km from the coast and approximately 100km east of Port Hedland along the Great Northern Highway and in close proximity to power, rail and port facilities. The Company believes there is significant potential to increase the size and value of the resource defined at Highway. The deposit remains open at depth and the company notes that previous resource calculations did not incorporate the significant cobalt values. A number of processing options to unlock the value of the inferred mineral resource of 130,000 tonnes of contained nickel in the Highway Deposit are being evaluated to determine the viability of the deposit as an open pit operation.

event_text: In all 22.25 line km data was collected at this prospect. event_text: Initial work in early 1989 by CRAE revealed the presence of base metals including nickel, zinc, lead and copper. Early diamond drilling at the Supply Well Prospect identified nickel and copper sulphides in diamond drill core. Consequently CRAEs exploration work in the area shifted to nickel, copper and some separate zones of sediment-hosted zinc mineralisation During 1988-1995, CRAE undertook detailed ground magnetic surveys, ground geophysical IP and EM surveys, broad regional airborne EM surveys and limited follow-up diamond, RC and RAB drilling over a large area known as the Worthy Project. CRAE drilled 693 holes totalling 22,355m during their period of exploration. The drilling included 632 RAB holes totalling 10,910m, 42 RC holes totalling 6,400m and 19 diamond drill holes totalling 5,045m.

event_text: Airborne magnetic and radiometric surveys were flown that enabled the detection and interpretation of the basement stratigraphy leading to the delineation of a major structural feature, the De Grey Structural zone largely hidden under sedimentary cover. Ground follow-up of magnetics and IP along this zone identified several IP anomalies over 8km of strike. Testing of the IP anomalies intersected some 50-100m widths of >10% pyrrhotite/pyrite mineralisation particularly in two holes at the Supply Well prospect. Due to the presence of massive sulphides, a trial GEOTEM survey was flown in 1990, which was successful in outlining sulphide mineralisation beneath up to 70m of Mesozoicaged cover. This subsequently led to a larger survey over the De Grey Structural Zone.
label: False

event_text: Several GEOTEM anomalies were identified from this airborne survey and were followed up with SIROTEM and ground magnetics. Drilling of SIROTEM and IP targets at Supply Well intersected cherts that contained 10-15% pyrite/ pyrrhotite. This intersection was considered stratabound, late-stage mineralisation associated with veins and fractures. Significant investigation and drilling failed to replicate these results. In 1992, further drill testing of identified GEOTEM anomalies, located several new areas of sulphides at the Highway prospect (14km to the south west of Supply Well).
label: True

event_text: SIROTEM was completed firstly over 400m then to 200m spaced lines. Drilling one conductor intersected a pyrite/ pyrrhotite zone containing 113m at 0.31% Ni and 0.31%Cu. event_text: Below is an excerpt from the explanatory note for the KELLERBERRIN sheet relevant to the project area. The topography is gently undulating, broken only by isolated hills which rise to 50 m above the surrounding country. Valleys are generally broad and flat bottomed. They contain braided and meandering stream channels and extensive chains of salt lakes with marginal lunette dunes. An extensive cover of lateritic soil developed on the plateau during the Late Cretaceous and Tertiary.

event_text: White to yellow sand (Gs) occurs widely along drainage divides. It is the remnant of a former continuous sandplain, now extensively reworked so that the sand veneer is much thinner on the top of hills than on the flanks, where it accumulates as colluvial deposits. Where there are extensive deposits of recent alluvium, it is difficult to determine whether Tertiary alluvium also occurs in the valleys, and a distinction between the two alluvial units Qa and Cza is uncertain. Tertiary alluvium (Cza) is identified as a flat surface on valley floors, on which present-day river meanders, braided drainage, and lake systems are developed. There is a sharp change in slope at the foot of the adjacent hills.

event_text: A series of calc-alkaline felsic (andesite with lesser dacite and rhyolite) volcanic complexes (Welcome Well, Edjudina) occur throughout the domain. They are the lowermost part of the regional stratigraphy in the Welcome WellMinerie district, although they overlie tholeiitic basaltic rocks in the YarriWallbrook district. Overlying these complexes are extensive mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks and intrusive equivalents. In the uppermost parts of the succession particularly in the Murrin Murrin and Eucalyptus districts are komatiitic basalt and lesser low-Mg komatiite and extensive ultramafic cumulate units. In the Spring Well district in the northern Murrin Domain, calc-alkaline felsic volcanism and associated sedimentary rocks are inferred to overly the mafic volcanic rocks.

event_text: Accordingly to Groenewald et al. (2006), the lowermost part of the succession is the Welcome Well Formation that consists of volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks that are predominantly andesitic in composition. Felsic volcanism is best preserved in the Welcome Well complex, which is dominated by felsic volcaniclastic rocks with subordinate felsic (andesite) and mafic (tholeiite) volcanic rocks and intruded by regionally extensive dolerite and gabbro sills (Giles & Hallberg, 1982; Hallberg, 1985). The Welcome Well Formation is overlain by the Minerie Formation that consists of tholeiitic to komatiitic basalts, with extensive dolerite and gabbro and interlayered with epiclastic sedimentary units. The basaltdominated succession is characterized by lateral and vertical transitions between massive coherent facies, pillow lava and autoclastic facies (Doyle et al., 2004).

event_text: The ultramafic cumulates are interpreted to be komatiitic in origin and their regolith is host to the Murrin Murrin lateritic Ni-Co deposit (Hill et al., 2001). In the south of the domain, are several fault-bounded successions of basalt with minor komatiite and dolerite and gabbro sills overlain by felsic volcaniclastic and metasedimentaryfelsic epiclastic units, and are truncated against the Kilkenny fault system. Small-scale trust duplexes and possible larger scale bedding-parallel faults imply repetition and/or juxtaposition of various supracrustal packages (Swager, 1995). In the DarlotSpring Well district in the northern part of the Murrin Domain, the greenstone succession consists of a basal basaltic package with rhyolite volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks and minor interflow metasedimentary units, overlain by felsic volcanic rocks of the Spring Well complex and more voluminous metasedimentary rocks considered to be distal equivalents of the Spring Well complex. A series of dolerite sills intrude the stratigraphic sequence at all levels.

event_text: The Mt Vetters project is in the Kalgoorlie region of the Norseman Wiluna greenstone belt in a district with a history of gold and nickel production, with the Cawse nickel laterite mine located to the south west of the project area. The project covers the southern portion of the Cawse Monzogranite and is covered by varying depths of alluvium. Limited previous exploration has been completed in the project area, with the extensive cover restricting the effectiveness of prospecting and surface sampling. Field inspection, GIS data compilation and interpretation and correlation with similar local and regional mineralisation styles and occurrences was completed.

event_text: Figure 8 below is an example of the detail of the accretionary textures seen in botryoidal goethite. Initial macroscopic assessment indicated that approximately half of these samples are dominated by goethite-limonite, some plus apparent hematite, with perhaps another half composed of ferruginised cherty silica. The extensive opaque component means that information from transmitted light microscopy (thin section) would be limited (including any recognition of asbestos minerals, which would be largely camouflaged by the opaque oxide). Analytical procedures to provide the required information was therefore considered to be by polished-section mineragraphic assessment of minerals (as far as possible with such goethitic-limonitic material), also study of textures with an attempt to offer comment on genesis, together with photomicrographs. Secondly, for XRD to perhaps more specifically identify the iron oxide minerals, and any other mineralogy, and also to check for any asbestos minerals.

event_text: Gold mineralisation in the Mosquito Creek Belt exhibits strong structural and lithological controls, from the regional scale through to the outcrop scale. Although structural timing relationships and wall-rock alteration paragenesis imply that mineralisation occurred late in the tectonic history of the belt, during D4, it is clear that the reactivation of earlier generations of structures also played an important role in controlling ore-fluid flow and the localisation of gold mineralisation. At the regional scale, the gold deposits along the Middle Creek line lie close to the northern margin of the D4 Kurrana Shear Zone, and, in the western part at least, are spatially associated with the series of mafic/ultramafic lenses that mark the trace of the D1 Middle Creek Fault (Figure 4).
label: False

event_text: The unifying characteristic of the mineralised quartz veins, and that which distinguishes them from the large number of barren D2 quartz veins further north, is the extent of modification by superimposed D4 deformation. Richly mineralised veins are i) strongly recrystallised, ii) commonly cut by late-stage, quartz and carbonate filled fractures, and iii) are surrounded by zones of D4 chloritisation, carbonation and faulting, that link ultimately to the margin of the Kurrana Shear Zone. 11 The exception to this style of mineralisation is the Golden Eagle deposit, in which there is no clear association between gold and quartz. However, there is a strong association between gold and late-stage, chlorite and pyrite rich, quartz filled fractures, which are attributed to deformation and fluid flux during D4. A working model for the gold deposits along the Middle Creek Line involves regional scale fluid transport within the Kurrana Shear Zone during D4, with secondary fluid flux into more discrete structures in the domain immediately north of the shear zone (i.e.
label: False

event_text: The D1 Middle Creek Fault, which is marked by the series of mafic/ultramafic rock lenses, probably played a role in regional fluid flux also, albeit in an indirect manner, by controlling the development of the D4 shear zone. Reactivation of D2 faults and vein margins in the vicinity of the boundary of the Kurrana Shear Zone was likely to have been promoted by high fluid pressure within the shear zone, and fluid flux into the secondary D2 structures was probably enhanced by their relatively higher permeability (due to a component of brittle behaviour). The main mechanism for gold deposition appears to have been declining temperature as the fluid moved away from the shear zone because, in detail, the richest gold mineralisation is generally not located directly in contact with the margin of the Kurrana Shear Zone. An alternative mechanism involving gold deposition due to decreasing or fluctuating fluid pressure at the shear zone boundary appears less likely given the distal position of the richest mineralisation. The gold deposits along the Blue Spec Line do not show an obvious association with a major ductile structure as is the case with the Middle Creek Line and the Kurrana Shear Zone.
label: True

event_text: Declining fluid temperature was unlikely to be the main mechanism for gold deposition because of the narrow width of the faults carrying the ore fluids. Given the evidence for crack-seal behaviour, a model involving gold deposition in response to pressure fluctuations at the brittle-ductile transition may be more appropriate. This model is in keeping with the generally higher crustal level features of the Blue Spec Line, such as the limited width of the primary conduits and the association of antinomy with gold mineralisation. At depth, the Blue Spec Line may be underlain by a broader zone of D4 shearing centred on the D1 Blue Spec Fault. Following the implementation and ultimate success of a revamped soil sampling technique in 2005, sampling programs were conducted throughout the Nullagine project area between 2005 and 2008.

event_text: An aeromagnetic survey was flown as a targeting tool for testing the inferred mafic/ultramafic stratigraphy below the Palaeozoic sediments. Due to the limited detail available within the existing widely spaced GSWA/BMR dataset, a high resolution airborne magnetic survey was undertaken to increase the capabilities of interpretation and give confidence in depth modelling. 3.1 Introduction and Background The Tjukayirla project is one of the few remaining unexplored regions of WA which still holds potential for a tier 1 high MgO NiS discovery with over 80km of prospective strike. Existing magnetic coverage over the Tjukayirla package was collected in 1976 at 3000m altitude; this survey identified a strong North-South magnetic feature with approximately 80km of strike flanked by weaker magnetic anomalies in what appears to be a classic BIF, mafic, ultramafic stratigraphy. Given that the presence of deep Proterozoic cover in the Eraheedy basin is well known, (300-600m over area of interest) it becomes necessary to establish depth to basement for explorable potential of this stratigraphy very early in the life of project.

event_text: The quality of the government dataset though of reasonable standard for the time of acquisition was clearly sub-optimal compared with currently available acquisition systems and after some preliminary modelling the decision to carry out a new high resolution survey over the tenement package was made, with the intent of increasing confidence in depth modelling and structural information. The survey was awarded to Fugro Airborne Surveys and flown in October 2006 over a period of 11 days with final processed data received in early December 2006. An extensive process of magnetic modelling in both 2.5D and 3D coupled with image processing was then carried out to maximise the value of the dataset and draw out any subtle features. Results of the modelling are discussed in 3.3. event_text: To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain. One hundred and twenty kilometres to the south-southeast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation. Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and high-Mg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons. The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain. However in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane.

event_text: The project consists of one Mining Lease, covering a total area of approximately 3km. The tenement is wholly owned by Terrain Minerals Ltd, with a royalty payable to Kambalda Mining NL of $10.00 per ounce of gold, up to the first 10,000 ounces produced from the tenements and thereafter $5.00 per ounce of gold. Gold mineralisation is widely distributed throughout the area, in a variety of rock types. The largest known deposit is the Coogee Prospect, with a resource of 230,000t @ 3.27g/t gold (24,000 oz), which is associated with a skarnoid calc-silicate alteration assemblage in sediments and volcanics. The top of the deposit is <25m below the surface and the primary mineralisation has been affected by supergene enrichment.

event_text: To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain. One hundred and twenty kilometers to the southsoutheast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation. Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and highMg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons. The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain. However, in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane.

event_text: If a drill hole had no ore grade above or below a mineralised intersection, and there was no indication of geological structural continuity, the ore block was terminated at the mid point between drill holes. If there was no drilling along strike from a section with ore intersections the ore zone was extrapolated an additional 5 metres along strike. It is common practice to extend zones of mineralisation that remain open along strike half the distance of the drill hole line spacing, in this case 10 metres. However, given the discreet nature of the mineralisation defined thus far, the mineralisation was only extended five metres east, and west of the end sections of drilling. The ore domain defined was saved as ore_interp_res1.

event_text: The Narlarla Project is centred on the Barker Gorge cutting the Napier Range. The old Narlarla (Devonian) lead-zinc-silver mine is located on the east side of the gorge on an elevated limestone plateau. The Barker River and Wombarella Creek drain an extensive catchment area of Proterozoic rocks forming part of the King Leopold Range. Water flow through the Barker Gorge during the wet season rains can be significant. In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla.

event_text: In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla. Thinner variants of this unit may be persistent throughout the area. The Frasnian platform facies Pillara Limestone is locally extensive, although not in the immediate Narlarla area, where the Frasnian Lower Napier and Famennian Upper Napier Formation are the dominant limestone units. Both are fore reef and slope facies carbonates containing locally abundant terriginous material in a variably bedded and dolomitised impure limestone. The Famennian reef margin Windjana Limestone and back reef Nullara Limestone are associated with the Upper Napier Formation elsewhere, but not in the immediate Narlarla area where they appear to have been removed by erosion (Hocking and Playford 1998).

event_text: 5 1.0 Summary The Narlarla Lead Zinc Project is centred on the Napier Range, immediately south of the Barker River, approximately 1,860 km north east of Perth in the West Kimberley region of Western Australia. The project area covers a portion of the north west corner of the Lennard River 1:250,000 map sheet (SE 51-8). The Napier Range consists of a narrow and elongate complex of Devonian reef carbonates that are prospective for hosting lead, zinc and silver mineralisation. The carbonates are surrounded by zones of basin fill sediments, and unconformably overlie Proterozoic metamorphic rocks. Increases in base metal prices during the year saw the project focus change from grass roots exploration to resource definition around the lead and silver mineralisation intersected during earlier drilling around the Narlarla Number 2 pit.

event_text: 25 3 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT APPENDICES 4 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT 1.0 INTRODUCTION This report discusses the Narlarla Pb-Zn resource in the Napier Range area in the West Kimberley, WA. An ore domain comprising zinc, lead and silver mineralisation has been defined around the abandoned number 2 pit that was last mined in 1965. The resource definition project has been managed by Coronet Resources Limited personnel. Whilst the area remains prospective for the definition of additional base metal mineralisation, this report will focus pre-dominantly on the resource area, and resource estimation process.

event_text: Vehicle access to the old Narlarla (Devonian) mine site on the limestone plateau immediately east of Barker Gorge is difficult. Access to the project area is generally good during the dry season, although the Napier Range itself is very rugged. Vehicle access to the project is often not possible during the northern Australian wet season. The Narlarla resource area is located on top of a plateau in the Napier Range, 13km NW of the Gibb River Road, next to the abandoned Number 2 pit. 5 3.0 HISTORY Zinc, lead and silver bearing gossans in the Narlarla area were discovered by a police patrol as early as 1901, with intermittent small scale mining activities taking place before and after World War 2.

Diamond drilling around the resource area has been planned. The three dimensional modeling package Surpac Vision V5.1-F was used in the construction of the resource block model.

event_text: 16 17 18 Future work planned, as a result of the data review includes: An extension of the ant mound, and soil sampling completed in the past; Ground truthing of geochemical anomalies, particularly those proximal to interpreted fault zones; Air core drilling; RC drilling; and Diamond drilling. During the year the priorities for the Narlarla Project changed from exploration to resource definition. This change was a result of the increasing base metal prices (particularly zinc) indicating that the zinc, lead, and silver mineralisation interpreted at the northern end of the old Number 2 Pit could potentially sustain a viable mining operation. All available data was reviewed, and a global resource defined. The Narlarla Project is located in the Napier Range within the north west portion of the Lennard Shelf, forming part of the northern margin of the Canning Basin in the West Kimberley.

event_text: The Narlarla Project is centred on the Barker Gorge cutting the Napier Range. The old Narlarla (Devonian) lead-zinc-silver mine is located on the east side of the gorge on an elevated limestone plateau. The Barker River and Wombarella Creek drain an extensive catchment area of Proterozoic rocks forming part of the King Leopold Range. Water flow through the Barker Gorge during the wet season rains can be significant. 7 8 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla.
label: True
LOCATION: Napier Range, King Leopold, Napier Range

event_text: 7 8 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla. Thinner variants of this unit may be persistent throughout the area. The Frasnian platform facies Pillara Limestone is locally extensive, although not in the immediate Narlarla area, where the Frasnian Lower Napier and Famennian Upper Napier Formation are the dominant limestone units. Both are fore reef and slope facies carbonates containing locally abundant terriginous material in a variably bedded and dolomitised impure limestone. The Famennian reef margin Windjana Limestone and back reef Nullara Limestone are associated with the Upper Napier Formation elsewhere, but not in the immediate Narlarla area where they appear to have been removed by erosion (Hocking and Playford 1998).
label: True
STRAT: Van Emmerick Conglomerate, Pillara Limestone, Napier Formation, Windjana Limestone, Nullara Limestone, Napier Formation

event_text: Bedded units dip on average 15 to 30 degrees to the south west; the steeper dips in fore reef slope areas. A northerly change in strike in the Barker Gorge area in the immediate vicinity of the Narlarla lead-zinc deposits has been interpreted as a syn-depositional feature associated with active faulting possibly along the present Barker River gorge (Ringrose, 1984). Lead-zinc mineralisation broadly of Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) is present in the area from Narlarla to Wagon Pass located approximately 14 kilometres to the north west. Although no presently economic reserves are known, the area is considered prospective in the light of significant lead-zinc mineralisation elsewhere on the Lennard Shelf. Approximately one third of the project area is composed of outcropping limestone of the Napier Range.

event_text: The regional geological setting for the Majestic group tenements is shown in Figure 3. Two thick, parallel Proterozoic east west dykes cut through P25/1710 and range from gabbroic to doleritic in composition. Gold mineralisation hosted in rocks of the Glandore Mafic Succession has been documented for a number of localities and mining centres. Mineralisation in the Mt Monger area is summarised in Hickman (1986). Past production from the Mt Monger mines has been in excess of 230,000 oz Au from over 1.1 million tonnes of ore mined.

event_text: Only P25/1709 remains under the management of Dioro Exploration NL and this expires in March 2009. During the year prior to expiry of the tenements and the agreement, a technical review of previous geochemistry and drilling was undertaken. It was concluded that while there were local strongly gold mineralised vein settings, these tended to be patchy and have limited strike and depth continuity. A well developed supergene enrichment process in the mafic rocks of the area has generated strongly anomalous gold values in the soils and in the weathered zone. Surficial coarse gold and nugget patches also occur in the area.

event_text: This mafic package is restricted to the western limb of the Bulong Anticline, extending from Glandore in the north through to Mt Monger in the south. The GMS is regarded as a separate thrust slice (D1) of the Gindalbie Terrain, which has subsequently been folded (D2) and offset by crosscutting (D3) faults. Gold mineralisation has been identified at a number of localities within the mafic package. During the 2005-2006 field season a detailed regional auger geochemical survey was completed. Samples were collected on a 160m x 40m spacing over the entire area of the three tenements.

event_text: The holes were completed at 80m intervals along nine lines between 160m and 400m spacings angled at -60 0 towards 090 0 (AMG East) Based on the results from this program an infill RAB drilling was then completed with a further seventy four holes (06MJRB132 205) for a total of 3892m drilled. The locations of all the RAB drilling is shown on the attached plan. The drilling produced a number of patchy narrow intersections which are tabulated below. The mineralisation appears to be confined to narrow relatively shallow west dipping zones within sheared basalts. A plan of the maximum gold values from the drilling together with the best intersections is attached.
label: True

event_text: Early in 2006 a proposal was put forward to carry out RC drilling totalling 1120m in 10 holes to follow-up the anomalous results from the RAB drilling. The RAB drilling intersected only narrow mineralised zones with only eight holes intersecting better than 1g/t Au. The drilling is of sufficient density to rule out the likelihood of there being any significant shallow saprolite hosted gold mineralisation. There is only one really significant intersection which was the 3m @ 12.2g/t Au in drill hole 06MJRB176 with the hole ending in mineralisation. Any gold mineralisation is likely to be narrow and of limited extent.

event_text: The central eastern parts of the Licence are underlain by ferricrete and Archaean sediments which trend northwesterly (figure 2). Granite has been mapped approximately 900m west of the Licence however the granite contact is considered to lie along the Licence boundary immediately west of the Dulcie West soil anomaly. Gold mineralisation along the Dulcie line occurs 2km across strike to the east and at British Hill 8km to the south east. Gold anomalism in soils and drillholes at Dulcie West defines a target approximately 2km in strike that has been sparsely drilled. Southern Cross Goldfields Ltd intends to further test this high priority target.

event_text: The adjacent units in the greenstone belt display structures that are compatible with this; stratigraphic contacts and foliations dip moderately to steeply away from the margins of the neighbouring dome, and the stratigraphic units concordantly wrap the domes. Post-tectonic (non-foliated) granitoids, discordant pegmatites and east-west striking mafic dykes have intruded the above-mentioned rocks. Regional metamorphic grade increases southwards through the district, from the lowest of grades in the Marda Complex, to quite high grade in the vicinity of Marvel Loch, and falls to low grade at Ravensthorpe. There is also a tendency for metamorphic grade to increase outwards towards the margins of the belt. 2 A consistent regional lithological layering, which is believed to have stratigraphic significance, is evident from the distribution of rock types around the granite domes.
label: True

event_text: 2 A consistent regional lithological layering, which is believed to have stratigraphic significance, is evident from the distribution of rock types around the granite domes. In a few localities, at the lowermost stratigraphic level is a thin interval of quartz-muscovite schist and quartzite which occurs in sheared contact with the gneissic granitoid on the western side of the Ghooli Dome. It is possible this is a basal sedimentation unit deposited on a stable basement; however this relationship has never been established. This unit is overlain in a structural sense by a thick mafic unit. Wherever unequivocal pillow facings have been documented in massive relatively undeformed tholeiitic basalt, they show facing away from the granite domes.

event_text: This iron-rich layer is interpreted to be a volcanogenic transitional unit between the mafic and sedimentary sequence, with exhalative features. The continuity of this same thick upper metasedimentary sequence well to the south into the Forrestania area is clearly established. Gold mineralisation in the region usually occurs with sulphide bearing quartz, localised by both structural and stratigraphic controls (Bagas, 1994). Host lithologies include mafic, ultramafic, BIF and sediment hosts. Work completed on the Licence included: interrogation of the database inherited from Polaris and International Goldfields compilation of historical data, aeromagnetics and geology to select gold and nickel targets field visits to determine access and check regional geology Interpretation of geology and aeromagnetic images (figures 2 and 3) shows the licence is traversed by three magnetic units 400-700m apart.

event_text: The lease is on the eastern flank of the Kambalda Dome 2km from the township of Kambalda in the Eastern Goldfields region of Western Australia, 60km south of Kalgoorlie. The Southern portion of the Long Victor Nickel Mine is on the lease. Nickel mineralisation is associated with Achaean ultramafic lava channels where molten and liquid nickel sulphides pool at specific points along the channels to a 40o dip to the east as well as resulting in the remobilisation of some of the original sulphides into new structurally imposed positions. To date, two channels have been recognised: Channel 1 - Victor Channel. The upper, high tenor nickel channel is interpreted to contain from north to south, the Gibb, Gibb South, Victor, Victor South and Mcleay deposits.

event_text: The Western Australian Kimberley Region is part of the North Australian craton such ancient stable crustal blocks are globally recognised as ideal settings for the occurrence of kimberlitic rocks. The Kimberley Region has been the focus of diamond exploration by a number of companies since the late 1960s, resulting in the discovery of the Ellendale and Argyle pipes (both active diamond mines, exploiting lamproite, a diamond host rock similar to kimberlite) in craton margin settings, and a significanat number of kimberlites and other lamproites with varying diamond content. The potential presence of kimberlite in the Escape Creek tenement area is based on the occurrence of numerous diamond indicator minerals and diamonds in relatively small catchments, as recorded by previous explorers in the region. The original area held is shown on Figure 1. The Escape Creek Project area is considered to be prospective for diamonds, and has been explored previously.

event_text: The first systematic exploration for diamonds in the Kimberley Region was in 1967 when a consortium of three small exploration companies were granted a Temporary Reserve on the northern margin of the Lennard Shelf area in the southwest Kimberley. Apart from sampling some of the outcropping lamproites, like Mount North, a combined aeromagnetic and radiometric survey of 1,777 line km was flown in 1968. The data were not considered sufficiently encouraging for ground follow up of some of the subtle magnetic anomalies. In 1969, gravel samples taken in the Lennard River near Police Camp Pool produced 9 small diamonds totalling 1.65 carats. Follow up sampling could not repeat this result.
